paragraph.content: shall forthwith give notice of his appointment to the Registrar in the specified form and give security in the prescribed manner to the satisfaction of the Official Receiver; (Replaced 46 of 2000 s. 25. Amended 28 of 2003 s. 79)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall give the Official Receiver such information and such access to and facilities for inspecting the books and documents of the company, and generally such aid as may be requisite for enabling that officer to perform his duties under this Ordinance.

section.name: s196
section.heading: General provisions as to liquidators

subsection.content: A liquidator appointed under section 194 may resign or, on cause shown, be removed by the court. (Replaced 46 of 2000 s. 26. Amended 14 of 2016 s. 35)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: A provisional liquidator appointed under section 194(1A) shall be remunerated—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in accordance with a scale of fees approved from time to time by the Official Receiver; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on such other basis as the Official Receiver approves in writing. (Added 46 of 2000 s. 26)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: Subsection (2) applies to a provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1)(aa) as it applies to a liquidator (other than the Official Receiver) and to avoid doubt, subsection (2) does not apply to determine the remuneration of the provisional liquidator in respect of the period before the making of the winding-up order. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 35)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1A), where a person other than the Official Receiver is appointed liquidator, he shall receive such remuneration by way of percentage or otherwise as is determined— (Amended 46 of 2000 s. 26)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where there is a committee of inspection, by agreement between the liquidator and the committee of inspection; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where there is no committee of inspection or the liquidator and the committee of inspection fail to agree, by the court,

subsection.continued: and if two or more persons are appointed liquidators, their remuneration shall be distributed among them in such proportions as may be determined by the committee of inspection or the court, as the case may be. (Replaced 25 of 1985 s. 3)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: If the Official Receiver is of the opinion that the remuneration of a liquidator as determined under subsection (2)(a) should be reviewed the Official Receiver may apply to the court, and the court may make an order confirming, increasing or reducing the remuneration of the liquidator. (Added 25 of 1985 s. 3)
A vacancy in the office of a liquidator appointed by the court shall be filled by the court.

If more than one liquidator is appointed by the court, the court shall declare whether any act by this Ordinance or the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) required or authorized to be done by the liquidator is to be done by all or any one or more of the persons appointed. (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s197
section.heading: Custody of company’s property
section.content: Where a winding-up order has been made or where a provisional liquidator has been appointed, the liquidator, or the provisional liquidator, as the case may be, shall take into his custody, or under his control, all the property and things in action to which the company is or appears to be entitled.

section.name: s198
section.heading: Vesting of property of company in liquidator
section.content: Where a company is being wound up by the court, the court may on the application of the liquidator by order direct that all or any part of the property of whatsoever description belonging to the company or held by trustees on its behalf shall vest in the liquidator by his official name, and thereupon the property to which the order relates shall vest accordingly, and the liquidator may, after giving such indemnity, if any, as the court may direct, bring or defend in his official name any action or other legal proceeding which relates to that property or which it is necessary to bring or defend for the purpose of effectually winding up the company and recovering its property.

section.name: s199
section.heading: Powers of liquidator in winding up by court

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 193(3), this section applies to a liquidator in a winding up by the court but does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Official Receiver holding office as a provisional liquidator by virtue of section 194(1)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1)(aa) or (1A).

subsection.content: A liquidator may exercise any of the powers specified in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 25 only with the sanction of the court or the committee of inspection.
Except as provided in subsection (4), a liquidator may exercise any of the powers specified in Part 3 of Schedule 25.

subsection.leadIn: A liquidator (other than the Official Receiver) may only exercise the power specified in item 8 of Part 3 of Schedule 25—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the sanction of the court or the committee of inspection; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: without the sanction if the liquidator has, before exercising the power, given at least 7 days’ notice of the intention to exercise the power—

subparagraph.content: (if there is a committee of inspection) to the members of the committee; or
(if there is no committee of inspection) to the creditors.

subsection.content: The exercise by a liquidator of the powers conferred by this section is subject to the control of the court.
A creditor or contributory may apply to the court on the exercise or proposed exercise of any of those powers.

section.name: s199A
section.heading: Powers of Official Receiver holding office as provisional liquidator by virtue of section 194(1)(a)

subsection.leadIn: The Official Receiver holding office as provisional liquidator by virtue of section 194(1)(a) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exercise any of the powers specified in Part 3 of Schedule 25; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exercise any of the powers specified in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 25 only with the sanction of the court.

subsection.content: The exercise by the Official Receiver of the powers conferred by this section is subject to the control of the court.
A creditor or contributory may apply to the court on the exercise or proposed exercise of any of those powers.

section.name: s199B
section.heading: Powers of provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1)(aa) or (1A)

subsection.content: Except as provided in subsection (3), a provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1)(aa) may exercise any of the powers specified in Part 1, 2 or 3 of Schedule 25 only with the sanction of the court.

Except as provided in subsection (4), a provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1A) may exercise any of the powers specified in Part 1, 2 or 3 of Schedule 25 only with the sanction of the court or the Official Receiver.

subsection.leadIn: A provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1)(aa) may without the sanction of the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take into the provisional liquidator’s custody, or under the provisional liquidator’s control, all the property and things in action to which the company is or appears to be entitled; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispose of the specified assets of the company to a person other than a relevant person.

subsection.leadIn: A provisional liquidator holding office by virtue of section 194(1A) may without the sanction of the court or the Official Receiver—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take into the provisional liquidator’s custody, or under the provisional liquidator’s control, all the property and things in action to which the company is or appears to be entitled; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispose of the specified assets of the company to a person other than a relevant person.

subsection.content: The Official Receiver is not personally liable for costs for any refusal to grant sanction under subsection (2) or (4).
The exercise by a provisional liquidator of the powers conferred by this section is subject to the control of the court.
A creditor or contributory may apply to the court on the exercise or proposed exercise of any of those powers.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: RelevantPerson
def.leadIn: relevant person (有關人士), in relation to a company, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a director or shadow director of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an associate, within the meaning of sections 265A(2), 265B and 265C, of the company or of any such director or shadow director;

def.name: SpecifiedAssets
def.leadIn: specified assets (指明資產) means any perishable goods or other assets (excluding derivatives, warrants, options, shares and things in action) the estimated value of which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is less than $100,000; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is likely to significantly diminish if they are not immediately disposed of.

section.name: s200
section.heading: Exercise and control of liquidator’s powers

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the liquidator of a company which is being wound up by the court shall, in the administration of the assets of the company and in the distribution thereof among its creditors, have regard to any directions that may be given by resolution of the creditors or contributories at any general meeting, or by the committee of inspection, and any directions given by the creditors or contributories at any general meeting shall in case of conflict be deemed to override any directions given by the committee of inspection.

The liquidator may summon general meetings of the creditors or contributories for the purpose of ascertaining their wishes, and it shall be his duty to summon meetings at such times as the creditors or contributories, by resolution, either at the meeting appointing the liquidator or otherwise, may direct, or whenever requested in writing to do so by one-tenth in value of the creditors or contributories as the case may be.
The liquidator may apply to the court in manner prescribed for directions in relation to any particular matter arising under the winding up.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the liquidator shall use his own discretion in the administration of the assets and the distribution thereof among the creditors. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 141)

If any person is aggrieved by any act or decision of the liquidator, that person may apply to the court, and the court may confirm, reverse, or modify the act or decision complained of, and make such order in the premises as it thinks just.

section.name: s201
section.heading: Books to be kept by liquidator
section.content: Every liquidator of a company which is being wound up by the court shall keep, in manner prescribed, proper books in which he shall cause to be made entries or minutes of proceedings at meetings, and of such other matters as may be prescribed, and any creditor or contributory may, subject to the control of the court, personally or by his agent inspect any such books.

section.name: s202
section.heading: Payments of liquidator into bank or Treasury

content.leadIn: Every liquidator other than the Official Receiver of a company which is being wound up by the court shall, in such manner and at such times as the Official Receiver directs, pay the money received by him to the Companies Liquidation Account at the bank where such account is kept, and when the Official Receiver is the liquidator of such company he shall pay all moneys received by him in such capacity into the Companies Liquidation Account:
content.proviso: Provided that the Official Receiver may, on the application of the liquidator, authorize the liquidator to make his payments into and out of any other bank specified by the liquidator in such application, and thereupon those payments shall be made in the prescribed manner. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 142; 30 of 1999 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the proviso to subsection (1), where any such liquidator (other than the Official Receiver) receives any money in such capacity, he shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a sum not exceeding $50,000, pay the money without any deductions therefrom to the Companies Liquidation Account not later than 14 days after its receipt;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of any other sum, forthwith pay the money without any deductions therefrom to the Companies Liquidation Account. (Replaced 30 of 1999 s. 16)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Where a liquidator retains any sum (including part of any sum) in contravention of subsection (2)(a) or (b), then, unless he explains the retention to the satisfaction of the court, he shall pay interest on the amount so retained at the rate of 20 per cent per annum, and shall be liable to disallowance of all or such part of his remuneration as the court may think just, and to be removed from his office by the court, and shall be liable to pay any expenses occasioned by reason of his default. (Added 30 of 1999 s. 16)
A liquidator of a company which is being wound up by the court shall not pay any sums received by him as liquidator into his private banking account.

section.name: s203
section.heading: Audit of liquidator’s accounts

subsection.content: The Official Receiver may at any time require a liquidator (other than the Official Receiver) of a company that is being wound up by the court to provide the Official Receiver, within the time limit specified by the Official Receiver, with an account of the liquidator’s receipts and payments as liquidator. (Replaced 22 of 2023 s. 19)
If a requirement is made under subsection (1), the liquidator must provide the account in the specified form within the time limit specified by the Official Receiver. (Replaced 22 of 2023 s. 19)

The liquidator shall furnish the Official Receiver with such vouchers and information relating to the account as he requires, and the Official Receiver may at any time require the production of, and inspect, any books or accounts kept by the liquidator. (Replaced 38 of 1987 s. 2)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: The Official Receiver may at any time cause the account to be audited. (Added 38 of 1987 s. 2)
When the account has been audited, the liquidator must deliver a copy of the account to each of the specified entities for filing. (Replaced 22 of 2023 s. 19)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: If the Official Receiver decides that the account need not be audited, the liquidator must, as soon as practicable after the decision, deliver a copy of the account to each of the specified entities for filing. (Added 22 of 2023 s. 19)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.leadIn: If a copy of the account is delivered by the liquidator to a specified entity under subsection (4) or (4A), the entity—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must keep the copy of the account so delivered to the entity in the manner that the entity thinks fit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must cause the copy of the account so kept by the entity to be open on payment of the prescribed fee to the inspection of any creditor, or any person having an interest, in the manner that the entity thinks fit. (Added 22 of 2023 s. 19)

content.leadIn: The liquidator shall, when the account has been audited or, when he has been notified that the Official Receiver has decided that the account need not be audited, send a printed copy of the account or summary by post to every creditor and contributory: (Amended 38 of 1987 s. 2; 14 of 2016 s. 38)
content.proviso: Provided that the Official Receiver may in any case dispense with compliance with this subsection. (Replaced 6 of 1984 s. 143)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the fact that a liquidator has been notified that the Official Receiver has decided that the account need not be audited, the Official Receiver may subsequently cause the account to be audited, and in that event—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the liquidator must deliver a copy of the audited account to each of the specified entities for filing; (Replaced 22 of 2023 s. 19)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: a specified entity must keep the copy of the audited account so delivered to the entity in the manner that the entity thinks fit; (Added 22 of 2023 s. 19)

paragraph.name: ac
paragraph.content: a specified entity must cause the copy of the audited account so kept by the entity to be open on payment of the prescribed fee to the inspection of any creditor, or any person having an interest, in the manner that the entity thinks fit; and (Added 22 of 2023 s. 19)

content.leadIn: the liquidator shall send a printed copy of the account or summary by post to every creditor and contributory: (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 38)
content.proviso: Provided that the Official Receiver may in any case dispense with compliance with this paragraph. (Added 38 of 1987 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified entity (指明單位) means—(a)the Official Receiver; or(b)the court. (Added 22 of 2023 s. 19)

section.name: s204
section.heading: Control of Official Receiver over liquidators

subsection.content: The Official Receiver shall take cognizance of the conduct of liquidators of companies which are being wound up by the court, and, if a liquidator does not faithfully perform his duties and duly observe all the requirements imposed on him by statute, rules, or otherwise with respect to the performance of his duties, or if any complaint is made to the Official Receiver by any creditor or contributory in regard thereto, the Official Receiver shall inquire into the matter, and take such action thereon as he may think expedient.

The Official Receiver may at any time require any liquidator of a company which is being wound up by the court to answer any inquiry in relation to any winding up in which he is engaged, and may, if he thinks fit, apply to the court to examine him or any other person on oath concerning the winding up.
The Official Receiver may also direct an investigation to be made of the books and vouchers of the liquidator. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 144)

section.name: s205
section.heading: Release of liquidators

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the liquidator of a company that is being wound up by the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: has—

subparagraph.content: realized all the property of the company, or so much of the property of the company that, in the opinion of the liquidator, can be realized without needlessly protracting the liquidation;
distributed a final dividend, if any, to the creditors; and
adjusted the rights of the contributories among themselves, and made a final return, if any, to those contributories;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has resigned or been removed from the office of liquidator; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has passed away. (Replaced 14 of 2016 s. 39)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The liquidator or (if subsection (1)(c) applies) the personal representative of the liquidator may apply to the court for the release of the liquidator. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 39)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: On an application under subsection (1A), the court is to cause a report on the accounts of the liquidator to be prepared. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 39)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.leadIn: On the liquidator or the personal representative of the liquidator complying with all the requirements of the court, the court may grant or withhold the release after having considered—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any objection against the release urged by a creditor or contributory or any person interested. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 39)

subsection.content: Where the release of a liquidator is withheld, the court may, on the application of any creditor or contributory, or person interested, make such order as it thinks just, charging the liquidator with the consequences of any act or default which he may have done or made contrary to his duty.

subsection.leadIn: An order of the court releasing the liquidator shall discharge him from all liability in respect of any act done or default made by him in the administration of the affairs of the company, or otherwise in relation to his conduct as liquidator, but any such order— (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 39)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does not prevent the exercise of the court’s powers under section 276; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be revoked on proof that it was obtained by fraud or by suppression or concealment of any material fact. (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 39)

subsection.content: Where the liquidator has not previously resigned or been removed, his release shall operate as a removal of him from his office.

section.name: s205A
section.heading: Interpretation of sections 205A, 207E, 207F, 207G, 207H and 207K and Division 6

subsection.leadIn: In this section and sections 207F, 207G, 207H and 207K and Division 6—

def.name: BusinessDay
def.leadIn: business day (辦公日) means a day that is not any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a general holiday;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Saturday;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a black rainstorm warning day or gale warning day as defined by section 71(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);

subsection.def: circulation date (傳閱日期)—see section 205B;

electronic address (電子地址) means any sequence or combination of letters, characters, numbers or symbols of any language or, any number, used for the purpose of sending or receiving a document or information by electronic means;

def.name: ElectronicRecord
def.leadIn: electronic record (電子紀錄) means a record generated in digital form by an information system, which can be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: transmitted within an information system or from one information system to another; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stored in an information system or other medium;

subsection.def: information (資訊、資料) includes data, text, images, sound codes, computer programmes, software and databases, and any combination of them;

def.name: InformationSystem
def.leadIn: information system (資訊系統) means a system that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: processes information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: records information;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: can be used to cause information to be recorded, stored or otherwise processed in other information systems (wherever situated); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: can be used to retrieve information, whether the information is recorded or stored in the system itself or in other information systems (wherever situated).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 207E, 207F and 207G and Division 6—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person sends a document, or supplies information, by post if the person posts a prepaid envelope containing the document or information addressed to the last known address of the recipient; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the document or information is to be regarded as having been received on the second business day after the day on which the document or information is sent or supplied, unless the contrary is proved.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 207K and Division 6—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a document or information is sent or supplied by electronic means if it is sent or supplied in the form of an electronic record to an information system;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document or information is to be regarded as sent or supplied by electronic means if it is sent or supplied by facsimile transmission; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a reference to an electronic address includes a facsimile number.

section.name: s205B
section.heading: Interpretation: circulation date
section.leadIn: For the purposes of section 205A—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: circulation date (傳閱日期), in relation to a proposed written resolution, means, subject to paragraph (b), the date on which copies of the resolution are sent to members of a committee of inspection for the purposes of section 207E(1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the copies of the resolution are sent to the members—

subparagraph.content: on the same day under section 207E(2), that day is taken to be the circulation date; and
on different days under section 207E(2), the first of those days is taken to be the circulation date.

section.name: s206
section.heading: Meetings of creditors and contributories to consider appointment of committee of inspection; constitution of committee of inspection

subsection.leadIn: When a winding-up order has been made by the court, it shall be the business of the separate meetings of creditors and contributories summoned for the purpose of determining whether or not an application should be made to the court for appointing a liquidator in place of the provisional liquidator, to determine further the following— (Amended 3 of 1997 s. 42; 14 of 2016 s. 42)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not an application is to be made to the court for the appointment of a committee of inspection to act with the liquidator; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a committee of inspection is appointed—subject to subsections (3) and (4), who are to be the members of the committee.

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), the court may make any appointment and order required to give effect to any such determination, and if there is a difference between the determinations of the meetings of the creditors and contributories in respect of the matters referred to in subsection (1) the court shall decide the difference and make such order thereon as the court may think fit.
A committee of inspection appointed under this Ordinance must consist of not less than 3, and not more than 7 members. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 42)

However, a liquidator may apply to the court for an order to vary the minimum or maximum number of members mentioned in subsection (3) and the court may make an order that it thinks fit. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 42)

subsection.leadIn: A committee of inspection appointed under this Ordinance must consist of creditors and contributories—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a proportion agreed on by the meetings of creditors and contributories; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the event of a difference, in a proportion determined by the court. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 42)

subsection.content: A body corporate may be a member of the committee but cannot act as a member otherwise than by a representative authorized under section 207A. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 42)

section.name: s206A
section.heading: Meetings of committee of inspection

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2), (3) and (4), meetings of a committee of inspection are to be held when and where determined by the liquidator.

subsection.leadIn: The liquidator must summon a first meeting of the committee to be held within 6 weeks from the date of the appointment of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the liquidator; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the committee,

subsection.continued: whichever is the later.

subsection.content: After the first meeting, if the liquidator receives a request in writing to summon a meeting of the committee from a member of the committee or the representative of a member, the liquidator must summon the requested meeting for a date not later than 21 days after the date the request is received.

subsection.leadIn: If the committee resolves at the first meeting or any subsequent meeting that a meeting is to be held—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a specified date, the liquidator must summon a meeting for that date; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on a specified date at a specified time, the liquidator must summon a meeting for that date and that time.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (6), the liquidator must give 5 days’ written notice of the date, time and place of a meeting to every member of the committee.

If the liquidator determines to hold a meeting in the manner referred to in section 207B, the liquidator must give 10 days’ written notice of the date, time and place of the meeting to every member of the committee.
The notice of a meeting may be given to a member’s representative designated for that purpose instead of a member.
The requirement to give notice may be waived by or on behalf of a member before or at a meeting.
In calculating the number of days mentioned in subsections (5) and (6), Saturdays and general holidays are to be excluded.

section.name: s207
section.heading: Proceedings of committee of inspection

subsection.content: A committee of inspection may act by a majority of their members present at a meeting, but shall not act unless a majority of the committee are present. (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 44)
A member of the committee may resign by notice in writing signed by him and delivered to the liquidator.

If a member of the committee becomes bankrupt, or compounds or arranges with his creditors, or is absent from 5 consecutive meetings of the committee without the leave of those members who together with himself represent the creditors or contributories, as the case may be, his office shall thereupon become vacant.

A member of the committee may be removed by a resolution at a meeting of creditors, if he represents creditors, or of contributories, if he represents contributories, of which 7 days’ notice has been given, stating the object of the meeting. (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 44)

Subject to subsections (7A) and (7B), on a vacancy occurring in the committee the liquidator shall forthwith summon a meeting of creditors or of contributories, as the case may require, to fill the vacancy, and the meeting may, by a resolution, re-appoint the same or appoint another creditor or contributory to fill the vacancy. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 145; 14 of 2016 s. 44)

subsection.name: 7A
subsection.leadIn: If the liquidator, having regard to the position in the winding up, is of the opinion that it is unnecessary for the vacancy in the committee to be filled, the liquidator may apply to the court and the court may make an order that the vacancy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does not have to be filled; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not have to be filled except in the circumstances specified in the order. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 44)

subsection.name: 7B
subsection.leadIn: The vacancy does not have to be filled if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the liquidator and a majority of the continuing members of the committee agree that, having regard to the position in the winding up, it is unnecessary for the vacancy to be filled; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the total number of continuing members of the committee is not reduced—

subparagraph.content: to less than 3; or
if the court has varied the minimum number of members, to less than the minimum number ordered by the court. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 44)

subsection.leadIn: The continuing members of the committee may continue to act despite any vacancy in the committee if the total number of continuing members of the committee is not reduced—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to less than 3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the court has varied the minimum number of members, to less than the minimum number ordered by the court. (Replaced 14 of 2016 s. 44)

section.name: s207A
section.heading: Representatives of members of committee of inspection

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (5), a member of the committee of inspection may, in relation to the business of the committee, be represented by a person authorized by the member for that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: A person is authorized by a member only if the person holds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a general power of attorney from the member; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a letter of authority that—

subparagraph.content: entitles the person to act as the member’s representative (either generally or specifically); and

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: (if the member is a natural person) by the member; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: (in any other cases) by or on behalf of the member.

subsection.content: A proxy given by a member of a committee of inspection in relation to a meeting of the creditors, of the members or of the contributories is treated as a letter of authority to act generally as the member’s representative in relation to the committee, unless the proxy contains a statement to the contrary.

subsection.leadIn: The chairperson of a meeting of the committee may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call on a person claiming to act as a member’s representative to produce the person’s general power of attorney or letter of authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exclude the person from the meeting if it appears that the person’s authority is deficient.

subsection.content: A member of the committee must not be represented by a body corporate, an undischarged bankrupt or a person who is subject to a voluntary arrangement with the person’s creditors.

subsection.leadIn: A person must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the same committee, act as the representative of more than one member at any time; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: act both as a member of the committee and as the representative of another member.

subsection.content: If the representative of a member signs a document on behalf of the member, the representative must state below the signature whether the representative is signing under a general power of attorney or under a letter of authority.
The acts of the committee are valid despite any defect in the authorization or qualifications of a member’s representative.

section.name: s207B
section.heading: Remote attendance at meetings of committee of inspection

subsection.content: This section applies to a meeting of a committee of inspection held under this Ordinance, except a meeting held under rule 74 of the Companies (Winding-up) Rules (Cap. 32 sub. leg. H).
If the liquidator considers it appropriate, the meeting may be held and conducted in a manner that enables persons who are not present together at the same place to attend it.

If the meeting is held and conducted in the manner referred to in subsection (2), a person attends the meeting if the person is able to exercise any rights of the person to speak and vote at the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is able to exercise the right to speak at a meeting if the person, during the meeting, is in a position to communicate to all those attending the meeting, any information or opinion the person has on the business of the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person is able to exercise the right to vote at a meeting if—

subparagraph.content: the person is able to vote, during the meeting, on resolutions or determinations put to the vote at the meeting; and
in determining whether such resolutions or determinations are passed, the person’s vote can be taken into account at the same time as the votes of all the other persons attending the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: If the meeting is to be held and conducted in the manner referred to in subsection (2), the liquidator must make the arrangements the liquidator considers appropriate to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enable those attending the meeting to exercise their rights to speak and vote;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: verify the identity of the persons attending the meeting; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ensure the security of any technology used to enable attendance.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement under section 206A(6) for notice to be given of a specified place for a meeting may be satisfied by specifying the arrangements the liquidator proposes to enable persons to exercise their rights to speak and vote if, in the reasonable opinion of the liquidator—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a meeting will be attended by persons who will not be present together at the same place; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is not necessary or expedient to specify a place for the meeting.

subsection.content: In making the arrangements mentioned in subsection (5) and in forming the opinion mentioned in subsection (6)(b), the liquidator must have regard to the legitimate interests of the members of the committee or their representatives attending the meeting in the efficient conduct of the business of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (6), the liquidator must specify a place for the meeting if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: because of subsection (6), the notice of the meeting under section 206A(6) is given without a place specified for the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one member of the committee requests the liquidator to specify a place for the meeting in accordance with section 207C.

section.name: s207C
section.heading: Procedure for requests that place for meeting should be specified under section 207B

subsection.content: This section applies to a request under section 207B(8)(b) to specify a place for the meeting.
The request must be made at least 5 days before the date of the meeting that is stated in the notice of the meeting given by the liquidator under section 206A(6).

subsection.leadIn: If the liquidator considers that the request has been made in accordance with this section, the liquidator must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: give written notice to all the persons who were given notice of the meeting under section 206A(6)—

subparagraph.content: that the meeting is to be held at a specified place; and
as to whether the date and time are to remain the same or not;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: set a date for the meeting, which must not be later than 7 days after the original date, and a time and place for it; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: give 5 days’ notice of the date, time and place to all the persons who were given notice of the meeting under section 206A(6).

subsection.content: The notices required by subsection (3)(a) and (c) may be given at the same time or at different times.

If the liquidator has specified a place for the meeting in response to a request to which this section applies, the liquidator, or a person appointed by the liquidator in writing, must attend the meeting in person at that place.
In calculating the number of days mentioned in subsections (2) and (3), Saturdays and general holidays are to be excluded.

section.name: s207D
section.heading: Written resolution of committee of inspection

subsection.content: Anything that may be done by a resolution passed at a meeting of the committee of inspection may be done, without a meeting and without any previous notice being required, by a written resolution of the committee.

A reference to the date of passing a resolution or the date of a meeting is, in relation to a written resolution of the committee, the date on which the written resolution is passed under section 207G(1).
A written resolution of the committee has effect as if passed by members of the committee at a meeting of the committee.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a resolution sanctioning the making of calls by a liquidator under section 226.
A resolution of the committee may be proposed as a written resolution only by the liquidator.

section.name: s207E
section.heading: Circulation of written resolution

subsection.content: A liquidator may seek to obtain the agreement of the members of the committee of inspection to a proposed written resolution by sending to every member of the committee a copy of the resolution.

subsection.leadIn: The liquidator may send a copy of the resolution under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by sending a copy to every member at the same time so far as reasonably practicable;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if it is possible to do so without undue delay, by sending—

subparagraph.content: the same copy to each member in turn; or
separate copies to each of a number of members in turn; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by sending copies to some members at the same time and sending a copy or copies to the other members in accordance with paragraph (b).

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, a copy of the proposed written resolution may be sent to a representative of a member designated for that purpose instead of the member and it is to be regarded as a copy sent to the member.

subsection.leadIn: The liquidator must ensure that the copy of the proposed written resolution sent under this section contains, or is accompanied by, the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: how to signify agreement to the resolution under section 207G;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date by which the resolution must be passed if it is not to lapse under section 207H(1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the right of the member to request a meeting under section 207F(1); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the date by which the request must be received by the liquidator under section 207F(2).

subsection.content: The validity of the resolution, if passed, is not affected by a contravention of subsection (4).

section.name: s207F
section.heading: Request for summoning meeting to consider resolution

subsection.content: A member of the committee of inspection or the representative of a member may request the liquidator to summon a meeting of the committee to consider the matters raised by the resolution sent under section 207E.

subsection.leadIn: The request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be received by the liquidator within 7 business days from the circulation date.

subsection.content: A request made in accordance with this section takes effect as a request made under section 206A(3).

section.name: s207G
section.heading: Procedure for signifying agreement to proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: A written resolution is passed when—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the members of the committee of inspection have signified their agreement to it; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a majority of the members of the committee have signified their agreement to it, and a period of 7 business days beginning on the circulation date has ended without any request to summon a meeting having been made under section 207F(1).

subsection.leadIn: A member of the committee signifies agreement to a proposed written resolution when the liquidator receives from the member or the member’s representative a written document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifying the resolution to which it relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: indicating the member’s agreement to the resolution.

subsection.content: A member’s agreement to a written resolution, once signified, may not be revoked.

section.name: s207H
section.heading: Period for agreeing to proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: A proposed written resolution lapses if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is not passed before the end of the period of 28 days beginning on the circulation date; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the liquidator receives from a member of the committee of inspection or the representative of a member a request made in accordance with section 207F to summon a meeting.

subsection.content: The agreement of a member of the committee to a proposed written resolution is ineffective if signified after the resolution lapses under subsection (1).

section.name: s207I
section.heading: Liquidator’s duty to notify members of committee of inspection that written resolution has been passed

subsection.content: If a written resolution of the committee of inspection is passed, the liquidator must, within 15 days after the resolution is passed, send a notice of this fact to every member of the committee.
A notice under this section may be sent to the representative of a member designated for that purpose instead of the member.

section.name: s207J
section.heading: Liquidator’s duty to keep record of written resolution that has been passed
section.leadIn: A liquidator must keep—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of every resolution passed as a written resolution of the committee of inspection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a note that all or a majority of the members of the committee have signified agreement to the relevant written resolution.

section.name: s207K
section.heading: Communication with liquidator by electronic means for the purpose of written resolution

subsection.leadIn: If the conditions in subsection (2) are satisfied, a member of a committee of inspection may send to a liquidator by electronic means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request under section 207F(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document signifying agreement to a proposed written resolution referred to in section 207G(2).

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the liquidator—

subparagraph.content: has agreed, generally or specifically that a document may be sent to the liquidator by electronic means; and
has not revoked the agreement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the liquidator is to be regarded as having so agreed as described in subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a document is sent to a liquidator by electronic means if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the document is sent to an electronic address—

subparagraph.content: specified for the purpose by the liquidator generally or specifically; or
regarded under subsection (4) as having been so specified for the purpose;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the document is sent in a form, and by a means, that, in the reasonable opinion of the member, will enable the liquidator to—

subparagraph.content: read the document, or, to the extent that it consists of images, to see the document with the naked eye or with a suitable corrective lens; and
retain a copy of the document;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the document is sent in the manner as described in section 205A(3)(a) or (b); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the document is authenticated in one of the following ways—

subparagraph.content: the identity of the member is confirmed in a manner specified by the liquidator;
if the manner has not been specified, the communication contains, or is accompanied by, a statement of the identity of the member, the truth of which the liquidator has no reason to doubt.

subsection.content: If the liquidator has given an electronic address in any document containing or accompanying a proposed written resolution of the committee, the liquidator is to be regarded as having agreed, subject to any conditions or limitations that the liquidator may have specified in the document, that any document relating to that resolution may be sent by electronic means to that address.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(a)(ii), an agreement to allow sending documents by electronic means is only to be regarded as having been revoked if the liquidator has given the member of the committee a notice of revocation of at least—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 7 days; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified for the purpose in any agreement between the liquidator and the members,

subsection.continued: whichever is the longer.

subsection.leadIn: If a document is sent to the liquidator in accordance with this section, unless the contrary is proved, it is to be regarded as having been received by the liquidator at the end of the following period after it is sent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period specified for the purpose in any agreement between the member of the committee and the liquidator; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if no period has been specified, 48 hours.

subsection.content: In calculating the period mentioned in subsection (6)(b), any part of a day that is not a business day is to be disregarded.
In this section, a reference to a member of a committee of inspection includes a representative of a member.

section.name: s207L
section.heading: Travelling expenses of members of committee of inspection

subsection.leadIn: The liquidator must defray as an expense of the winding up any reasonable expenses incurred directly by a member of the committee of inspection or the representative of a member in respect of travelling within Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend the committee’s meetings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the committee’s business.

subsection.content: The payment by the liquidator mentioned in subsection (1) is subject to the order of priority prescribed in this Ordinance.

section.name: s208
section.heading: Powers of court where no committee of inspection
section.content: Where in the case of a winding up there is no committee of inspection, the court may, on the application of the liquidator, do any act or thing or give any direction or permission which is by this Ordinance authorized or required to be done or given by the committee.

subdivision.name: SD8
subdivision.heading: General Powers of Court in case of Winding Up by Court

section.name: s209
section.heading: Power to stay winding up

subsection.content: The court may at any time after an order for winding up, on the application either of the liquidator, or the Official Receiver, or any creditor or contributory, and on proof to the satisfaction of the court that all proceedings in relation to the winding up ought to be stayed, make an order staying the proceedings, either altogether or for a limited time, on such terms and conditions as the court thinks fit.

On any application under this section the court may, before making an order, require the Official Receiver to furnish to the court a report with respect to any facts or matters which are in his opinion relevant to the application.
A copy of every order made under this section shall forthwith be delivered by the company, or otherwise as may be prescribed, to the Registrar. (Added 6 of 1984 s. 146)

section.name: s209A
section.heading: Power of court to order winding up to be conducted as creditors’ voluntary winding up

subsection.leadIn: The court may on the application of the liquidator or any creditor made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a company in respect of which an order has been made under section 227F, not later than 3 months from the date of such order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, not later than 3 months from the date of a resolution to make such an application passed at any of the meetings (including an adjourned meeting) of creditors and of contributories held pursuant to section 194 or such further time as the court may permit,

subsection.continued: order that the winding up of a company ordered to be wound up by the court shall, from the date of the order made on such application, be conducted as if the winding up were a creditors’ voluntary winding up.

subsection.leadIn: Where an application is made under subsection (1), the court shall have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the wishes of the creditors and contributories of the company, as proved to it by sufficient evidence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the progress of the winding up (including in particular assets realized, proofs of debts submitted by creditors and whether a statement of affairs, or a supplementary affidavit (if required), has been submitted under section 190); (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 47)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: whether any report has been made to the court under—

subparagraph.content: section 191(1); or
section 191(2) that in the liquidator’s opinion a fraud has been committed;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether any director, former director or other officer of the company has been convicted under the pre-amended Ordinance, this Ordinance or any other law for any offence involving fraud, dishonesty, fraudulent trading, misfeasance or breach of duty in relation to the affairs of the company; (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: whether any criminal proceedings in respect of any offence referred to in paragraph (d) are contemplated or have been instituted against any person referred to in that paragraph;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: whether the company forms part of a group of companies the affairs of which are proposed to be investigated or are being investigated under— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subparagraph.content: a provision of the pre-amended Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11 to the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) or by virtue of section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);
this Ordinance; or
any other law; (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: whether there has been a failure on the part of the directors to provide a statement of affairs, or a supplementary affidavit (if required), which the court considers satisfactory or to co-operate with the Official Receiver or liquidator or to comply with any requirement under this Ordinance in relation to the winding up of the company; (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 47)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: whether any director or former director of any other company which has gone into liquidation within 5 years of the date when the company went into liquidation, has been directly or indirectly concerned in the management of the company;
the fact that the insolvency of the company is a matter of public concern; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: any other matter which the court considers appropriate in the particular circumstances.

subsection.content: Where an application has been made under subsection (1) in relation to a company in respect of which an order had been made under section 227F then, without affecting the generality of subsection (2)(a) and subject to subsection (4), the court shall before hearing the application direct that meetings of the creditors and contributories be called, held and conducted in such manner as the court may direct for the purpose of ascertaining the wishes of the creditors and contributories and may appoint a person to act as the chairman of any such meeting and to report the result of the meeting to the court.

Where the court is of the opinion that it is impractical to hold meetings of the creditors or of the contributories, the court may order that such other course of action as directed by the court be taken to ascertain the wishes of the creditors and contributories.

In an order made under this section, notwithstanding any other provision of this Ordinance, the court may, after taking into consideration the wishes of the creditors and contributories, direct either that the liquidator of the winding up by the court appointed under section 192 continue to act as the liquidator or appoint any other person to act as the liquidator.

subsection.leadIn: Where an application is made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the liquidator shall; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Official Receiver may,

subsection.continued: submit to the court a report with regard to the application. (Replaced 46 of 2000 s. 28)

subsection.content: On the hearing of any application made under subsection (1), the Official Receiver may appear and call, examine or cross-examine any witness if he so thinks fit and may support or oppose the application.

section.name: s209B
section.heading: Consequences of an order under section 209A
section.leadIn: Where an order is made under section 209A that the winding up of a company shall be conducted as if it were a creditors’ voluntary winding up—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the date of—

subparagraph.content: the commencement of the winding up shall be the date deemed under section 184 to be the date of the commencement of the winding up by the court;
the appointment of the liquidator shall be the date of the appointment (or first appointment) of a provisional liquidator in the winding up by the court; and
the order for winding up shall be the date on which the order for winding up by the court is made,

paragraph.continued: for any purpose for which the date of the commencement of the winding up, the date of the appointment of a liquidator or the date of the winding-up order respectively is relevant under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sections 182, 183 and 186 shall continue to apply;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the rights of a creditor or a contributory under section 257 shall not be affected;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the fees of the liquidator and any charges or expenses due and payable under section 296 or under any other provision in this Ordinance up to the date of the order made under section 209A shall be paid forthwith out of the assets of the company in priority to all the other claims;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the statement of the affairs of the company, and any supplementary affidavit in relation to that statement, required to be submitted under section 190 and the accounts of the liquidator up to the date of the order made under section 209A may be inspected by the creditors; (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 48)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any creditor is entitled to have a copy of any document referred to in paragraph (e) on payment of reasonable photocopy charges (if any);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the court shall make such other orders as it considers appropriate to safeguard the books, records and documents of the company in the custody of the liquidator or the Official Receiver, and notwithstanding section 283 or any other provision of this Ordinance or the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) they shall not be disposed of otherwise than as specified in such order. (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s209C
section.heading: Transitional

subsection.content: Any application for an order that the winding up of a company ordered to be wound up by the court be conducted as if it were a creditors’ voluntary winding up made before the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) (No. 4) Ordinance 1990 (59 of 1990) (in this section referred to as the amending Ordinance) shall be considered or continued with as if the amending Ordinance had not been enacted.

The liquidator or any creditor of any company in respect of which an order for winding up by the court was made after 30 August 1984 and before the commencement of the amending Ordinance may, before the expiration of 3 months from that commencement, apply to the court for an order that such winding up be conducted as if it were a creditors’ voluntary winding up and the provisions of section 209A in force immediately before the commencement of the amending Ordinance shall apply to that application as if the amending Ordinance had not been enacted.

section.name: s210
section.heading: Settlement of list of contributories and application of assets

subsection.leadIn: As soon as may be after making a winding-up order, the court shall settle a list of contributories, with power to rectify the register of members in all cases where rectification is required in pursuance of this Ordinance or the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), and shall cause the assets of the company to be collected, and applied in discharge of its liabilities: (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 49)
subsection.proviso: Provided that, where it appears to the court that it will not be necessary to make calls on or adjust the rights of contributories, the court may dispense with the settlement of a list of contributories.

subsection.content: In settling the list of contributories, the court shall distinguish between persons who are contributories in their own right and persons who are contributories as being representatives of or liable for the debts of others.

section.name: s211
section.heading: Delivery of property to liquidator
section.content: The court may, at any time after making a winding-up order, require any contributory for the time being on the list of contributories, and any trustee, receiver, banker, agent or officer of the company to pay, deliver, convey, surrender, or transfer forthwith, or within such time as the court directs, to the liquidator any money, property, or books and papers in his hands to which the company is prima facie entitled.

section.name: s212
section.heading: Payment of debts due by contributory to company and extent to which set-off allowed

subsection.content: The court may, at any time after making a winding-up order, make an order on any contributory for the time being on the list of contributories to pay, in manner directed by the order, any money due from him or from the estate of the person whom he represents to the company, exclusive of any money payable by him or the estate by virtue of any call in pursuance of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The court in making such an order may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an unlimited company, allow to the contributory by way of set-off any money due to him or to the estate which he represents from the company on any independent dealing or contract with the company, but not any money due to him as a member of the company in respect of any dividend or profit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a limited company, make to any director or manager whose liability is unlimited or to his estate the like allowance.

subsection.content: In the case of any company, whether limited or unlimited, when all the creditors are paid in full, any money due on any account whatever to a contributory from the company may be allowed to him by way of set-off against any subsequent call.

section.name: s213
section.heading: Power of court to make calls

subsection.content: The court may, at any time after making a winding-up order, and either before or after it has ascertained the sufficiency of the assets of the company, make calls on all or any of the contributories for the time being settled on the list of the contributories to the extent of their liability, for payment of any money which the court considers necessary to satisfy the debts and liabilities of the company, and the costs, charges, and expenses of winding up, and for the adjustment of the rights of the contributories among themselves, and make an order for payment of any calls so made.
In making a call the court may take into consideration the probability that some of the contributories may partly or wholly fail to pay the call.

section.name: s214
section.heading: Payment into bank of moneys due to company

subsection.content: The court may order any contributory, purchaser or other person from whom money is due to the company to pay the amount due into such bank as the court may direct to the account of the liquidator instead of to the liquidator, and any such order may be enforced in the same manner as if it had directed payment to the liquidator.

All moneys and securities paid or delivered into any bank pursuant to this Part in the event of a winding up by the court shall be subject in all respects to the orders of the court. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 148)

section.name: s215
section.heading: Order on contributory conclusive evidence

subsection.content: An order made by the court on a contributory shall, subject to any right of appeal, be conclusive evidence that the money, if any, thereby appearing to be due or ordered to be paid is due.
All other pertinent matters stated in the order shall be taken to be truly stated as against all persons and in all proceedings.

section.name: s216
section.heading: Appointment of special manager

subsection.content: Where the Official Receiver becomes the liquidator of a company, whether provisionally or otherwise, he may, if satisfied that the nature of the estate or business of the company, or the interests of the creditors or contributories generally, or there are other grounds therefor, require the appointment of a special manager of the estate or business of the company other than himself, apply to the court, and the court may on such application, appoint a special manager of the said estate or business to act during such time as the court may direct, with such powers, including any of the powers of a receiver or manager, as may be entrusted to him by the court. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 149; 46 of 2000 s. 29)
The special manager shall give such security and account in such manner as the court may direct.
The special manager shall receive such remuneration as may be fixed by the court.

section.name: s217
section.heading: Exclusion of creditors not proving in time

subsection.content: The court may fix a date on or before which creditors are to prove their debts or claims.

Any creditor who has not proved his debt or claim on or before the date fixed under subsection (1) shall be excluded from the benefit of the distribution made next after that date and from the benefit of any previous distribution.

section.name: s218
section.heading: Adjustment of rights of contributories
section.content: The court shall adjust the rights of the contributories among themselves, and distribute any surplus among the persons entitled thereto.

section.name: s219
section.heading: Inspection of books by creditors and contributories

subsection.content: The court may, at any time after making a winding-up order, make such order for inspection of the books and papers of the company by creditors and contributories as the court thinks just. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 151; 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Where an order for inspection is made under subsection (1), creditors or contributories may, in accordance with the order but not further or otherwise—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inspect any books or papers in the possession of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the books or papers are kept by the company by recording the contents of the books or papers otherwise than in a legible form, inspect a reproduction of the recording or the relevant part of it in a legible form. (Added 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be taken as excluding or restricting any rights or powers conferred on a public officer by any enactment. (Added 6 of 1984 s. 151)

section.name: s220
section.heading: Power to order costs of winding up to be paid out of assets
section.content: The court may, in the event of the assets being insufficient to meet the costs, charges and expenses incurred in the winding up, make an order as to the payment thereof out of the assets in such order of priority as the court thinks just.

section.name: s224
section.heading: Power to arrest absconding contributory or officer
section.content: The court, at any time either before or after making a winding-up order, on proof of probable cause for believing that a contributory or any past or present officer of the company has absconded or is about to quit Hong Kong or otherwise to abscond or to remove or conceal any of his property for the purpose of evading payment of calls or debts due to the company or of avoiding examination respecting the affairs of the company, may order that the contributory or officer be arrested and his books and papers and movable personal property seized and him and them safely kept until such time as the court may order.

section.name: s225
section.heading: Powers of court cumulative
section.content: Any powers by this Ordinance conferred on the court shall be in addition to and not in restriction of any existing powers of instituting proceedings against any contributory or officer or debtor of the company, or the estate of any contributory or officer or debtor, for the recovery of any call or other sums.

section.name: s226
section.heading: Delegation to liquidator of certain powers of court
section.leadIn: Provision may be made by general rules for enabling or requiring all or any of the powers and duties conferred and imposed on the court by this Ordinance in respect of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the holding and conducting of meetings to ascertain the wishes of creditors and contributories;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the settling of lists of contributories and the rectifying of the register of members where required, and the collecting and applying of the assets;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the paying, delivery, conveyance, surrender or transfer of money, property, books or papers to the liquidator;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the making of calls;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the fixing of a date on or before which creditors are to prove their debts or claims, (Replaced 6 of 1984 s. 157)

section.continued: to be exercised or performed by the liquidator as an officer of the court, and subject to the control of the court:
section.proviso: Provided that the liquidator shall not, without the special leave of the court, rectify the register of members, and shall not make any call without either the special leave of the court or the sanction of the committee of inspection.

section.name: s226A
section.heading: Dissolution of company otherwise than by order of court

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a company in respect of which the following conditions are satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the affairs of the company have been completely wound up; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the liquidator has been granted his release by order of the court under section 205,

subsection.continued: the Official Receiver or the liquidator may deliver to the Registrar a certificate in the specified form, signed by the Official Receiver or the liquidator, as the case may be, stating that the company is a company in respect of which those conditions are satisfied.

content.leadIn: The Registrar shall forthwith register any certificate delivered under subsection (1), and on the expiration of 2 years from the registration thereof the company shall be dissolved:
content.proviso: Provided that the court may, on the application of the Official Receiver or the liquidator, make an order deferring the date at which the dissolution of the company is to take effect for such time as the court may think fit.

subsection.content: The Official Receiver or the liquidator who has obtained an order under subsection (2) shall, within 7 days after the making of the order, deliver an office copy of the order to the Registrar for registration. (Replaced 28 of 2003 s. 81)

section.name: s227
section.heading: Dissolution of company by order of court

subsection.content: When the affairs of a company have been completely wound up, the court, if the liquidator makes an application in that behalf, shall make an order that the company be dissolved from the date of the order, and the company shall be dissolved accordingly.
A copy of the order shall within 14 days from the date thereof be delivered by the liquidator to the Registrar for registration.
If the liquidator makes default in complying with the requirements of this section, he shall be liable to a fine and, for continued default, to a daily default fine. (Amended 7 of 1990 s. 2)

subdivision.name: SD9
subdivision.heading: Winding Up by Court with Regulating Order

section.name: s227A
section.heading: Court may make a regulating order

subsection.content: Where it appears to the court on application being made by the Official Receiver, provisional liquidator or liquidator or by any creditor at any time after the presentation of a winding up petition that by reason of the large number of creditors or contributories or for any other reason the interest of the creditors so requires, it may, on or after the making of a winding-up order, order that the winding up of the company by the court shall be regulated specially by the court, and such order shall be known as a regulating order. (Amended 6 of 1984 s. 159; 14 of 2016 s. 52)
Where a regulating order is made it shall be published in such manner as the court may direct, and sections 227B to 227E inclusive shall apply to the winding up.

Where a regulating order is made the Companies (Winding-up) Rules (Cap. 32 sub. leg. H) shall apply mutatis mutandis to the Official Receiver, liquidator and committee of inspection appointed or acting after the making of a regulating order, and to the conduct of any ballot or other proceedings ordered by the court under section 227C or 227D.

Where any order made under section 227B, 227C or 227D prescribes any procedure it shall be deemed to be in substitution for the procedure which would be required by this Ordinance but for the making of such order, and in particular where any such order prescribes a procedure for doing something which would otherwise be done at a meeting of creditors or contributories no such meeting shall be required to be held.

section.name: s227B
section.heading: Appointment of liquidator and committee of inspection

subsection.leadIn: The court may, on the application of the Official Receiver or provisional liquidator, by order— (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 53)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: dispense with the summoning of first meetings of creditors and contributories as required under sections 194 and 206 for the purpose of considering the appointment of a liquidator and a committee of inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: appoint one or more persons that the court thinks fit as a liquidator or liquidators; and (Replaced 14 of 2016 s. 53)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: as regards a committee of inspection—

subparagraph.content: appoint any qualified persons that the court thinks fit as a committee of inspection;
remove any member of the committee; and
fill any vacancy in the committee. (Replaced 14 of 2016 s. 53)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The court may, on the application of the liquidator, by order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint any qualified persons that the court thinks fit as a committee of inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remove any member of the committee; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fill any vacancy in the committee. (Added 14 of 2016 s. 53)

subsection.content: Where under subsection (1) or (1A) the court makes any appointment of a liquidator or a committee of inspection, or where it removes any member of such committee of inspection or fills any vacancy therein, it shall not be necessary to ascertain the wishes of the creditors or contributories, and the provisions of section 194(1)(b) or 206(1) and (2) or 207(6), (7), (7A) and (7B), as the case may be, shall cease to apply and any action taken under such provisions in respect of any appointment of a liquidator or committee of inspection or any removal therefrom or any filling of any vacancy therein shall cease to have effect. (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 53)

section.name: s227C
section.heading: Informing creditors and contributories and ascertaining their wishes and directions
section.leadIn: The court may vary the procedure for ascertaining the wishes and directions of creditors and contributories, and for keeping such creditors and contributories informed as to any matter relating to the winding up, and for such purposes the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that the Official Receiver or liquidator inform the creditors and contributories of such matters in such manner as it may direct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of sections 200 and 287 order that the wishes of creditors and contributories be ascertained by the Official Receiver or liquidator in such manner as it may direct;

content.leadIn: for the purposes of section 200 order that the wishes of the creditors and contributories ascertained pursuant to paragraph (b) be reported by the Official Receiver or liquidator to the court, which may thereupon give such directions as it sees fit, and that notwithstanding section 200(2) the liquidator shall not be required to summon any meetings of creditors or contributories:
content.proviso: Provided that nothing in section 227A(4) or in this paragraph shall operate to prevent any person making application to the court under section 200(5);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: order that instead of the same being sent by post as required under section 203(5) the account of the liquidator or a summary thereof be communicated by the Official Receiver or liquidator to the creditors and contributories in such manner as it may direct. (Amended 14 of 2016 s. 54)

section.name: s227D
section.heading: Compromises and arrangements with creditors

subsection.content: For the purposes of section 670 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), the court may despite subsection (1) of that section order that the wishes of creditors or contributories concerning agreement to or rejection of any compromise or arrangement be ascertained by the liquidator in such manner as it may direct including the conduct of a ballot and the use of voting letters and without holding meetings.

Where a majority in number and three-fourths in value of the creditors, or a class of creditors, as the case may be, who have proved their debt, or who by virtue of section 227E are deemed for voting purposes to have proved a debt exceeding $250, agree to any compromise, such agreement shall, for the purposes of section 673 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), have the same effect as if a meeting of the creditors or class of creditors had been summoned under section 670(1) of that Ordinance and a majority in number representing three-fourths in value of the creditors or class of creditors, as the case may be, had been present and voted either in person or by proxy at the meeting and agreed to the compromise. (Amended 81 of 1976 s. 3)

In the event of the court ordering the holding of any meetings it may order that the provisions of this Ordinance, or of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), relating to the holding of meetings be varied, abrogated or added to for the purpose of such meetings.

subsection.def: In subsection (1) arrangement (安排) has the meaning given by section 668(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622). (Replaced 79 of 1988 s. 6)

section.name: s227E
section.heading: Proof of debts

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a bank, any creditor who is a depositor, whether on current, savings, deposit, fixed deposit or other account, shall, unless and until the Official Receiver or liquidator by notice in writing requires him to make a formal proof of debt, be deemed to have proved his debt—

paragraph.name: a
